Goorian Hero Review - Empires and Puzzles Strategy Guide

Goorian brings a massive bone club and an even bigger attitude to the Slime family. With a 480% hit-all nukes and a defense down that rivals the best, he is a slow-speed disaster waiting to happen for your enemies. Plus, he turns into a blob when he dies. What's not to love?
Goorian: The Barbaric Sludge Who Refuses to Wipe
Goorian, The Barbaric Sludge: Smashing Bones and Spawning Blobs

Goorian is a 5-star Legendary Nature hero from the Slime family, released via the Super Elemental Summon in March 2025. He fits the classic mold of the "slow but devastating" juggernaut. While the game has sped up significantly, Goorian reminds us that sometimes, waiting for the big hit is worth it. He combines a massive Area of Effect (AoE) nuke with a crippling defense down, making him a modernized, slimy version of some of the game's hardest hitters. He doesn't just hit you; he breaks your armor and then refuses to die thanks to his annoying Slime mechanics.

Visually, Goorian is a treat. He looks like an orc who fell into a vat of radioactive lime jelly and decided to embrace the lifestyle. He is wielding a comically large bone club and seems to be in an intense standoff with a delicate butterfly, which is a hilarious contrast to his "Barbaric Sludge" title. The green-on-green aesthetic screams Nature element, and the translucent slime effects on his body are well-rendered. He looks squishy yet solid, perfectly capturing the Slime family theme.

Goorian boasts an Attack stat of 1266 and a Power of 1184 (base). When he was released in early 2025, these were top-tier numbers. However, looking at the meta in December 2025, with heroes like Devyani pushing 1300+ Attack and 1230+ Power, Goorian has slid slightly from the bleeding edge. He is still statically robust, far superior to older Season 1-4 heroes, but he sits comfortably in the "strong modern" category rather than "god-tier stat monster." His defensive stats are balanced, leaning slightly towards health, which synergizes well with his Mega Minion passives.
"Bone Slam" is a special skill that demands respect. Dealing 480% damage to
enemies is a multiplier usually reserved for sniper heroes hitting one target or slow heroes hitting three. Applying this to the entire enemy team is devastating.

But the damage is just the opener. The -40% defense down to all enemies is the real star here. This isn't just a static debuff; it degrades further by -5% every time the target is hit, capping at -60%. This makes him an incredible setup hero for Titans or for a follow-up wipe in Rush wars.

is his insurance policy. If he dies with this effect active (which lasts 2 turns), he comes back as a Slime. If you can't kill the Slime in 3 turns, he reverts to his original form with inherited health and mana. This mechanic forces the opponent to waste attacks on a "dead" hero or risk facing a fully charged Goorian all over again.

Goorian is Slow. In a vacuum, he needs 12 tiles. With a level 29 Magic troop (or similar high-end mana troop) and a Bard bonus or emblem nodes, you can shave this down, but he will rarely outpace the Average/Fast meta without Rush Attack rules.

With a base attack of roughly 1266 (before troops/LB), a 480% hit deals approx 6076 raw damage value distributed across 5 heroes. Against a modern team with ~1500 defense, this is still a massive chunk of HP, likely stripping 30-40% of their health bar in one go.

Starting at -40% and potentially reaching -60% effectively increases all subsequent damage taken by the enemy by roughly 50-80%. This is mathematically superior to almost any other AoE defense down in the game.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Slime family is notoriously annoying to deal with because they introduce "Mega Minions" into the equation, which act as substantial meat shields.

The bonus enhances the Attack of all minions and fiends based on the number of Slime heroes. While nice, you are likely running Goorian for his own merits rather than trying to force a full Slime team, unless you have the roster depth.
These passives are Goorian's true survival kit.

If a sniper hits him for >25% of his HP (which is common given he is slow and will take hits before firing), he instantly spawns a Mega Minion with 50% HP. This can interrupt kill combos and keep him alive just long enough to fire.
Even if he dies, he leaves behind a parting gift—Mega Minions for his neighbors. This provides a safety net for your remaining team.

is a fantastic Aether power for an AoE damage dealer. Boosting his attack at the start of the battle helps compensate for any attack reduction debuffs and ensures that when he finally does fire, it hits like a truck.
Upon release, Goorian was seen as a "Rush War Monster" and a "Titan Specialist." He was the answer for players wanting a green AoE Defense Down hero who hit harder than Frigg or Brienne (costumed).

By late 2025 standards, 480% damage to all is still excellent, but "Slow" speed is a harder sell in standard raids where "Very Fast" heroes dominate. His stats have held up reasonably well, though he lacks the "Wither" or "Growth" mechanics seen in the absolute newest heroes like Devyani.

in Very Fast wars and tournaments. He is also a staple for high-level Titan teams due to the scaling defense down. In standard PvP, he is niche—best used when you can protect him or accelerate his mana.
At the time of writing, Goorian does not have a costume. This review focuses on his base form.

Goorian is a Barbarian. This class offers the "Wound" talent (bleed damage), which is nice but not game-changing. The primary decision is whether to boost his survivability to ensure he fires, or his attack to maximize the wipe potential.
Maximizes the 480% damage multiplier. In Rush wars, if he fires, the enemy team likely evaporates.
Being Slow, he might die before casting if the board is bad.
Synergizes with his Passive (Mega Minion HP is based on his max HP). Makes him incredibly hard to remove, increasing the chance he survives to use Bone Slam.
Sacrifices the "one-shot" potential of his special.

path is safer. Because he is Slow, your priority is ensuring he survives to fire his special at least once. His base damage percentage is high enough that he will still hurt, but a dead Goorian deals 0 damage. Plus, beefier stats mean beefier Mega Minions.
480% to all enemies is one of the highest multipliers for a hit-all skill.
-40% to -60% defense down is elite for Titans and raid wipes.
Between the Passives (Mega Minion on damage) and the Slime Revive, he is very "sticky" and hard to permanently remove.
Scaling defense down is invaluable for high scores.
Without Rush rules or mana acceleration, he can be too slow for the modern fast-paced meta.
His Revive buff can be dispelled (before he turns into a slime) or blocked.
If an enemy uses "Bypass" or anti-minion tech, his survivability drops significantly.
This is his playground. With Very Fast mana, he becomes an absolute nightmare to face.
Great for clearing waves of mobs and boss stages where speed is less critical.
He can tank or flank in Rush wars effectively.
Mother North - Goorian - Khufu - Alfrike - Kalø
A classic "toxic" Rush defense. Goorian softens them up (defense down), and Khufu finishes them off. Mother North keeps everyone alive.
Tarlak/Miki (Attack Boost) - Goorian (Def Down) - Evelyn/Almur (Elemental Def Down) - Ratatoskr (Tile Boost) - Strongest Sniper
Goorian provides the general defense down slot, replacing older options like Buddy or Dolgoon.
Hel, Proteus, or newer mana blockers shut him down completely. Since he is slow, he takes forever to recover.
Heroes like Grimsteel or Ogima who destroy minions or punish them are dangerous, as they negate his passive protection.
If blocked, he won't get his Slime Revive buff, making him permanently killable.

If you pulled Goorian early, congratulations! He will carry you through map stages effortlessly. Don't worry too much about his slow speed early on; his raw power will obliterate low-level teams. Prioritize keeping him alive with healers.

Goorian is a luxury tool. He is not a "must-have" for your primary raid offense unless you lack modern hit-all heroes. However, he is worth maxing for your Rush War depth and for pushing Titan scores. Do not prioritize Alpha Aethers on him unless you are competitively playing in top 100 Rush Wars.
The community reaction to Goorian was a mix of awe at his damage and skepticism about his speed.
"Modern day AOE Athena." — A player noting the potency of his defense down.
Many compared him to heroes like
, noting that 450%+ to all used to come with drawbacks (like self-defense down), but Goorian gets upsides instead.

"Goorian has arrived - and nobody cares." — Initial forum reaction was lukewarm because he launched during a busy birthday portal, flying under the radar until people realized how annoying his revive mechanic was.

Goorian is the definition of a "force multiplier." He hits hard, makes everyone else hit harder via defense down, and refuses to leave the battlefield without a fight. While he may be too sluggish for the hyper-speed daily raids, he remains a titan in Rush formats and PvE. He might look like a goofball with a bone club, but ignore him at your peril.
Verdict: A Rush War King and Titan Slayer. Keep him, feed him, and watch him squash things.
